speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the pain and swelling in your left knee? Is it constant, or does it come and go, and have you noticed any triggers that make it worse?

speaker: Patient
text: It's been getting progressively worse over the past two months, to be honest. The pain is usually worse at night, and it's hard to explain, but it feels like it's always there, even when I'm resting.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities, do you engage in any sports or physical activities that might have put additional stress on your knee, and have you noticed any redness or warmth around the affected area?

speaker: Patient
text: I do some light exercise at work, like climbing stairs, but I don't think that's the main cause. And as for redness or warmth, I've noticed the knee does get a bit red and warm, especially after I've been sitting or standing for a while, but it's not extremely red or inflamed.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your knee's range of motion? Is it limited, or can you still bend it fully without any significant pain? Also, have you noticed any locking or catching sensations in your knee, or is it more of a dull ache?

speaker: Patient
text: I'd say my knee's range of motion is a bit restricted, especially when I first get up in the morning. It takes a bit of time to loosen up, but once I'm moving around, it's not too bad. As for locking or catching sensations, I don't really experience that, but I do feel a bit stiff, especially after a long day.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to perform a physical examination of your knee to get a better sense of what's going on. Can you please stand up and slowly bend your knee, keeping it straight, and then straighten it out for me? Also, I'd like to request an X-ray of your left knee to get a better look at the joint and surrounding bone structure. REQUEST TEST: X-ray of Left Knee.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital_Signs: NORMAL READINGS Knee_Examination: Inspection: Mild swelling observed around the left knee. Palpation: Tenderness upon palpation, no warmth. Range_of_Motion: Limited by pain, particularly on extension and flexion. Special_Tests: McMurray test negative, Lachman test negative, Anterior and posterior drawer tests negative tests: X-Ray_Left_Knee: Findings: A lytic lesion in the distal femur near the knee joint with a thin rim of bone on the external surface and a'soap bubble' appearance.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you first noticed the lytic lesion in your X-ray? Was it after a fall, or did it develop gradually over time? Also, I'd like to request an MRI of your left knee to get a better look at the joint and surrounding soft tissues. REQUEST TEST: MRI of Left Knee.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital_Signs: NORMAL READINGS Knee_Examination: Inspection: Mild swelling observed around the left knee. Palpation: Tenderness upon palpation, no warmth. Range_of_Motion: Limited by pain, particularly on extension and flexion. Special_Tests: McMurray test negative, Lachman test negative, Anterior and posterior drawer tests negative tests: X-Ray_Left_Knee: Findings: A lytic lesion in the distal femur near the knee joint with a thin rim of bone on the external surface and a'soap bubble' appearance. MRI_Left_Knee: Findings: A lesion in the distal femur with clear demarcation and non-invasive characteristics, suggestive of a benign process.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the activities you've been doing since the lytic lesion appeared on your X-ray? Have you noticed any changes in your knee's stability or sensation, such as numbness, tingling, or a burning feeling?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I've been trying to keep my usual routine as much as possible, but I have noticed that the pain and stiffness in my knee have made it a bit more difficult to engage in certain activities, like hiking or playing sports. I've also had to adjust my work schedule a bit to avoid exacerbating the issue.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your work schedule adjustments? Have you had to take any time off from work due to your knee, and have you noticed any differences in your overall quality of life since the lytic lesion appeared on your X-ray? Also, I'd like to request a bone scan to further evaluate the lesion. REQUEST TEST: Bone Scan.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital_Signs: NORMAL READINGS Knee_Examination: Inspection: Mild swelling observed around the left knee. Palpation: Tenderness upon palpation, no warmth. MRI_Left_Knee: Findings: A lesion in the distal femur with clear demarcation and non-invasive characteristics, suggestive of a benign process.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your work schedule adjustments? Specifically, have you noticed any changes in your daily activities or habits that might be contributing to the progression of the lytic lesion?

speaker: Patient
text: I've had to take a few days off from work to rest and ice my knee, which has been a challenge since I'm an engineer and usually work on tight deadlines. I've also started taking the stairs more often at work instead of the elevator, which has helped a bit, but I still have to be mindful of my activities to avoid making it worse.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've reviewed the X-ray and MRI results, and I'd like to ask a few more questions. Can you tell me more about your knee's sensation? Do you experience any numbness, tingling, or a burning feeling, especially when you're standing or walking? Also, I'd like to request a CT scan of your left knee to get a better look at the distal femur and surrounding bone structure. REQUEST TEST: CT Scan of Left Knee. Please wait for the results before continuing.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital_Signs: NORMAL READINGS Knee_Examination: Inspection: Mild swelling observed around the left knee. Palpation: Tenderness upon palpation, no warmth. Range_of_Motion: Limited by pain, particularly on extension and flexion. Special_Tests: McMurray test negative, Lachman test negative, Anterior and posterior drawer tests negative Sensation: No numbness, tingling, or burning feeling observed.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask a few more questions to help narrow down the possible causes of the lytic lesion. Can you tell me more about your knee's sensation when you're bearing weight? Does it feel stable, or does it feel like it's going to give way? Also, I'd like to request an EMG test to evaluate the nerves in your knee. REQUEST TEST: EMG of Left Knee.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital_Signs: NORMAL READINGS Knee_Examination: Inspection: Mild swelling observed around the left knee. Palpation: Tenderness upon palpation, no warmth. Range_of_Motion: Limited by pain, particularly on extension and flexion. Special_Tests: McMurray test negative, Lachman test negative, Anterior and posterior drawer tests negative Sensation: When bearing weight, the sensation is stable, but there's a feeling of slight instability, particularly when extending the knee.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this feeling of slight instability when extending your knee? Does it feel like it's going to give way or is it more of a slight wobble sensation? Also, I'd like to request a review of your work schedule and daily activities to see if there's anything that might be contributing to the progression of the lytic lesion. Have you noticed any changes in your posture or gait since the lesion appeared on your X-ray?

speaker: Patient
text: It's hard to describe, but when I extend my knee, I feel like there's a slight... hesitation, I guess, before it fully straightens out. It's not like it's going to give way or anything, but it's like my knee is trying to catch up with itself, you know? And it's not just when I'm extending my knee, it's also when I'm bearing weight on it, like when I'm standing or walking. And yeah, I've noticed that I've been leaning a bit more to the right when I'm walking, trying to distribute the weight more evenly, but I'm not sure if that's just a habit or if it's related to the lesion. I've also been trying to pay more attention to my posture and make sure I'm not putting too much strain on my knee, but it's hard to know for sure. I've also been doing some research on my own, reading about different types of bone lesions and trying to learn more about what might be going on with my knee. I just want to understand what's happening and find a way to manage the pain and discomfort.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this feeling of slight instability when extending your knee? You mentioned it's like your knee is trying to catch up with itself. Is there any sensation of pain or discomfort associated with this feeling, or is it more of a neutral sensation?

speaker: Patient
text: It's more of a neutral sensation, to be honest. It's not really painful, but it's just... unsettling, I guess. Like my knee is hesitating for a split second before it can move again.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the activities you've been doing since the lytic lesion appeared on your X-ray? Have you noticed any changes in your knee's stability or sensation, such as numbness, tingling, or a burning feeling, when you're engaging in activities like climbing stairs or walking? Also, I'd like to request a review of your medical history, have you had any previous knee injuries or surgeries that might be contributing to the progression of the lytic lesion?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been trying to maintain my usual routine, but the pain and stiffness have made it challenging to do certain activities, like hiking or playing sports. When I'm climbing stairs, I do feel a bit of a wobble sensation in my knee, but it's not severe. As for numbness, tingling, or burning feelings, I haven't really noticed anything unusual, but I do get a bit of a dull ache when I'm standing or walking for long periods.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the dull ache you experience when standing or walking for long periods? Is it constant or does it come and go, and have you noticed any triggers that make it worse? Also, I'd like to request a review of your medication list, have you been taking any new medications or supplements that might be contributing to the progression of the lytic lesion?

speaker: Patient
text: The dull ache is more of a persistent feeling, to be honest. It's not really constant, but it's always there, especially after I've been standing or walking for a while. I've noticed that it's a bit worse when I've been sitting for a long time, like when I'm working on a project or watching TV.

text: The EMG test, that's a good idea, I've heard it can help diagnose nerve damage. speaker: Doctor
text: Thank you for the additional information. I'd like to request the EMG test results to see if there's any nerve damage or irritation that could be contributing to the symptoms. Also, I'd like to request a review of your job duties as an engineer, specifically any tasks that involve repetitive knee movements or bending. Please wait for the EMG test results before continuing. Can you tell me more about your knee's sensation when you're standing on uneven surfaces or slopes? Does it feel stable, or does it feel like it's going to give way?

speaker: Patient
text: I think it's a bit more unstable when I'm standing on uneven surfaces or slopes, to be honest. It's like my knee is trying to compensate for the instability, but it's not quite sure how to do it, you know? It's not a sharp pain, but more of a... a feeling of uncertainty, like my knee is hesitating for a split second before it can adjust to the new surface.

speaker: Doctor
